In all the system of Farming and Garden
ing there is not more useful tool than the
Roller. Most of the complaints we receive
of seeds not growing, is owing to their not
being rolled. Celery, Spinage, Onion, and
indeed almost every other kind of seeds, will
not vcgetate, except the ground is rolled af-
ter the seed is sown, or except heavy rain
falls, to beat the ground, which answers the
same purpose. Where there is no roller
on the premises, the following may answer
as substitutc:--


After the seed is sown, and the ground
well raked, take board or boards. Of the
whole length of the beds-lay them fat on
the ground, beginning at one edge of the bed
walk the whole length of the board this
will press the soil on the seed: then shift the
board, till you have thus gone over the
whole bed; and in dry weather cover your
seed beds for forty eight hours with boards
laid fiat on the soil, and the seeds will come
up almost Immediately; and if no boards are
at hand tread in the seed with your feet, OF
strike on the beds with the blade Of your
spade or shovel.

"Never trust to hosters when you are on
journey. 1t is essentially necessary that
you personally see to the cleaning, watering,
feeding, and littering of your herse, other
wise you will in all probability soon be un-
der the necessity of purchasing another, or
abandoning your journey.


"Shopld your horse lose his appetite, give
him half an ounce of nitre in bran mash
once or twice. This, with little rest, will
soon recover him.


''Should you be so unfortunate as to have
your horse foundered, by injudicious feeding
or watering before he is sufficiently cool
which is always to be apprehended when you
feed on Indian corn, or any other grain ex-
cept oats; it is advisable on the first appear
ance of founder, to take two quarts of blood
from the neck, and also to bleed in two
places lin each foot) i'll the coronet or upper
edge Of the hoof, about one inch each way
from the centre, then give purge of castor
oil one pint, calomel one drachm, after this
and if it is possible to get him out of the sta
BILE, force him to take some exercise; which
is of all others the most efficacieus remedy
and ifperseyered in however cruel and pain
full it may appear to be, seldom or never
fails to carry off the complaint in shor,
time, especially if the founder or stiffness is
not very severe. But should it be founl
impracticablc to move the horse out of q
stable, which is sometimes the case, after
hsing bled as before directed, bran poultice

Mr.. Starr-I hand you for the amusement
and information of the practical farmer,
description which have verbally received
from friend of mine, living in that vicini.
ty, Of large Barn, built The last season, in
the town of Hancock Berkshire county Mass.
by the family of Shakers located in that
town. 1t is possible that in some points the
dimensions may be inaccurate; but you may
rely that they are materially correct.-Bcth
the size and form are probably unfit for any
common purposes very few farmers would
wish to collect so much forage and manure,
OF have so much stock at one place; but all
who have any experience in the business,
will agree that there is much ingenuity and
convenience in the design, for large estab-
Gshment.


The barn is built on ground inclning
southwardly, in perfect circle, and is nine
ty feet in diameter, or across 1t from side to
side. The walls are stone. % feet in height,
OF suitable thickness, and laid in lime or well
pointed on each side. Round the barn, on
the inner side, are stables forming circle,
the manger within, and suitable places over
il throw the hay or feed down; the stable
and manger occupy about 10 feet, and are 8
feet high the stables open to and from sew
eral different yards, in order to make
as many and such divisions Of their stock as
they have thought proper. The covering Of
che stables form the barn floor, which also
extends round the barn. There is but enc
large door way for entrance with teams and
loads; this is from the Northern side, from
an offset or causeway, eight feet above the
base, and of course fourteen feet below the
caves. The cart or wagon that enters with
a load, makes the whole circuit of the floor,
and after unloading comes out at the same
door; thus or 10 teams can occupy the floor
at one time in unloading, and not hinder each
other. Within this circle of the stables and
barn floor is an area or bay, as it is usually
called, which is filled with hay, &c, and
must be over sixty feet in diameter This
is pitched in and on from any side or place
most convenient, or where wanted.


The roof comes to point at the centre,
and sheds off the rain all around, something
similar to an umbrella. 1t is supported from
the inner circle of the barn floor The ROOT
boards are laid up and down, which by a
traverse saving Of the log we're all brough,
to point, and then shingled round in the u
sual mode.

on hand al reduced prices, whole sale or retail
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give us a call, as we have a
general assortment, consisting of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles Of various qualities; PANEL, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soncd; hearts Pine and Helnlock boIds; scant-
ling ard DIST of various qualities, lengths and
sizes; Poplar Plank, Boards and scantling; plain,
speeked and cnrlcd Maple Boards, Plank and
Scantling. Also, Cherry Scantllng; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and i variety Of other
articles not enumerated


n. b. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business will find il much to their adj
vantage to make application TO us, as We are
disposed TO sell on reasonable terms; and the
stand is we'll known 10 be as good as any i'll the
borough.


EZRA IIOOPES,

will continue the business in all its branches, at
the old Siiind, corner Of Tatnall and Queen-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,

plexion-had on when lie went way, suit u

brought home. All persons are cautioned

THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION Of St.
Peters Church. in the Borough of Whining
ton, return their unfeigned thanks to their Ex-
cellencics, the late and present Governors: and
also to the Honorable gentleme that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State OF Dcla-
ware, since the wear of our Lord 1922 to this
present wear of our ortts 1927, for their kind be-
ne, olence, founded on Christian philanthropy,
in extending the right hand offelowship, to their
Catholic brethren, (not in fleetlng words, but IN
real actions) to accomplish what was not IN our
power to do; which was, to finish our church,
and ay Oh the inc,imbranccs due on the church;
bv granting us lottery, and extending It, by
granting us two supplements; one Of which we
have The proceeds, received BY the Lottery and
first supplements; which was divided into four
different classes was received BY William Iarkin,
Grocer in the aforesaid thorough of Wilmington,
who acted as principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums ut money obtain
ca hy the sales Of the aforesaid four different
classes Of said Laftety-which money, the SAID
William I.arkin illegally holds from us, the Ma
nagers for the Congregation of st. Peters
Church, although we have repeatedly called on
the saitl William Larkin during the TING and term
of near five wears from the commencement OF
the firsi class Of the said Lottery, And for his
so illegally Withholding the money obtained by
the sales OF the aforesaid LOTTERY, We nave
suit at Law against the said William Larkin' as
we could not get a settlement from hun, but a
busive language and insolence, every time We
applied 10 him for such settlement.


we, the Managers Of St. Peters Church, give
tho public in general notice, that we discharge
the aforesaid William Larkn from our employ
and forbid him to transact any business as Ma
nager, Agent or for any concern, direct,
ly or indirectly, belonging to ST. Peters Church,
in the liorongh Of Wilmington, state Of pela,
ware-And also give the public notice that we
will not acknowledge nor abide by any transac.
ton done for the Church by any person Or per
sons, unless legally empowered by the Manag-
ers.


PETER PIERCE,


BERNARD M'GUIGEN,


BERNARD M'CANN,

There is great profit in feeding geese, tur-
keys, and fowls Of every sort, with potatoes
and meal mixed; they will tatten in nearly
half the time that they will with any kind OF
corn or even meal by itself. The potatoes
must be bruised fine, while they are hot, and
the meal added, when the mess is given to
them y SIC. IF .4rts.

Mr.. Someryille says that the fattening Of
hogs by potatoes, is much hastened, by mix
ing small quantity Of astringent substance
among the potatoes, especially if they show
the least tendency to purging. A little alum
or Armenian bole may be used.-Re7aort Of
The British Board Of Agricul.

may be applied to his legs and feet, kept
constantly wet with cold water.


"Clysters of three quarts of warm water,
naxseed tea, or water cruel, ought also to be
given. and repeated, if necessary, with
handful of fine salt in either. While the
stiffness continues, the horse should be fed
upon bran mashes. with small quantity OF
oats added, and be allowed but little water,
and that not entirely cold. Exercise must
on no account be omitted.


Deane's New England Farmer says "lo
fit horse for journey, he should not be sui
fered to grow too fat and gross. lie should for
some time be kept in the stable rather than
in the pasture. and fed mostly with proven
der: but rather sparingly if he incline to be
fat He should have exercise daily to hard
en- his flesh, and keep him in the habit Of
travelling. He should be shod some days
before he begins journey, that the shoes
may be well settled to his feet, and the nails
a little rusted at the points, that they hold
the faster And the pads of the saddle should
be we'll fitted to his back SO as to hill the
holows, and bear equally on every part
And while he is on a journey he should be
stabbed every night. 1t is very destructive
! to expose horses to the dampness and cold
of the night after severe exercise. But It
would be best if neither horses nor any OF
our cattle were wholly confined to dry meat
in winter. Horses indicate this by their cat
ing snow with their hay Set basket OF
! snow within reach of horse, when he is at
his manger, and he will take mouthful
4 from each alternately. OF all juicy food for
horses in winter, writers seem to give car
rots the preference. Potatoes and turnips
! in small quantities are also recommended.
1 They have been found by experience to an
swer well instead of oats for laborng horses;
and to fasten those which are lean. Carrots
are said in the Domestic Encyclopedia to be
particularly seryiceable to broken wlnded
horses.


"Horses should not be too much deprived
of the liberty of motion, they too often
are. Close confinement after hard labour,
will be apt to abate their circnlations too
suddenly. make them chilly, and stlffcn their
joints. Horses should therefore not be
straitened for room in their stables. Stables
should not be 50 low as to prevent their toss
ing up their heads as high as they please.
Some stables have so little room over head
as to bring horses into a habit OF carrying
] their heads too low. They become afraid
TO lift them up. They should also have room
in their stables to turn their heads to any
part of their bodies, that they may defend
themselves from the biting Of insects, alav
itching, &C. And their halters should al,
ways be SO long, and their stables so wide
that they may lay conveniently Nor should
horses be so placed as to be able to deprive
each other of fodder


"Horses that are daily worked in sum-
mer, should be mostly kept on green fodder
in stables, rather than grazed in pastures
he tendance Of them will not be 50 BURDEN
some, with spot Of high and thick grass
at hand, as leading them to and from pas
tnre at the distance of quarter Of mile.
This will prevent their being often chilled
by feeding il wet nights. A large quantity
of manure will thus he saved. And verv
small quantity Of land will answer in compar-
ison with what it takes for the pasturng of
horse. Keeping sctthe and basket at
hand, horse may De pastured in this way.
IN two or three minutes, and by the time that
! the whole spot has been once moved over,
that which is first cut will be grown again.

lowing letter. dated from the Temple Lon
don, received BY friend of his in this coun-
try, for the character of tenant quitting a
farm, regarding it as novel and curious to
agrculturists-to London agents ingenious
and instructive--and comprehensive and
amusing to the public:


Sir-I take the liberty of troubling YOU
with few inquiries, in consequence Of an
application made to me bv ----, who says
he has rented farm under you, and can re-
fer to you for his character and respectable
ty. for permission TO take an assignment of Il
lease of farm. of which have the controul
You will therefore oblige me by informing
me what is his character. Whether he is
honest, sober, frugal, industrious? Wheth-
er he is observant of his engagement with
his landlord and others Whether he is CON
tented or encroaching, compliant or obsti-
nate, cunning or sincere, good tempered or
churlishe W neither he stands TO his word or
takes all such advantages as he legally can?
what capital You suppose him to haves-
what sort OF an education he has had; whc-
ther he is intelligent or stupid, eager to ac-
quire new information in matters Of farming
or adheres to that which contented his grand
tathers-whcther he has an improved meth
cd of farming9 Does he lay his dung ON for
wheat, or for his turnips, beans and clovers,
Does he drill or use broadcast Does he
hoe any. and what cropss Does he use two
or four horses in his plough Does he feed
his hay grass, or NOV it? How many sheep
per acre did he keep on your farml How
many crops running did he use to take, or
would he have taken, if he had been per-
mittede Did he leave the land clean for the
incoming tenant especially were his last
years wheat stube clean, Did he buy
much hay or other fodder. and bring on the
farm, or did he sell hay and straw during his
term, OF at the end OF III Does he soil his
beasts and horses Did he keep his fences
good and accurate, and attend nicely to the
doing of his REPAIRS, Did he thrash by hand
or machlnee Is he L sportsman Is he
careful in increasing manuref and does he
lay 1t on the land hot and fresh, or keep it
TIL It is rotten? Was il upon the chalk land
that he held farm under you, or upon the
sand gravel, or clay?


1 he answer to some of these queries NAV
not, perhaps, be within your knowledge, and
unless yon take pleasure in farming; but il
you would answer such as YOU can. YOU
would confer on me favour. If leisure
should permit you to address line to me hy
Sunday next, should thankfully acknowl.
edge the obligation.


IS. Does he lay out money with spirit il
cleaning, manuring, and improving land, o,
is he close?

full articles.headline: ROLLING OF SEEDS.
full articles.article:
In all the system of Farming and Garden
ing there is not more useful tool than the
Roller. Most of the complaints we receive
of seeds not growing, is owing to their not
being rolled. Celery, Spinage, Onion, and
indeed almost every other kind of seeds, will
not vcgetate, except the ground is rolled af-
ter the seed is sown, or except heavy rain
falls, to beat the ground, which answers the
same purpose. Where there is no roller
on the premises, the following may answer
as substitutc:--


After the seed is sown, and the ground
well raked, take board or boards. Of the
whole length of the beds-lay them fat on
the ground, beginning at one edge of the bed
walk the whole length of the board this
will press the soil on the seed: then shift the
board, till you have thus gone over the
whole bed; and in dry weather cover your
seed beds for forty eight hours with boards
laid fiat on the soil, and the seeds will come
up almost Immediately; and if no boards are
at hand tread in the seed with your feet, OF
strike on the beds with the blade Of your
spade or shovel.

full articles.headline:
From the New-Englsnd Farmer.


HORSES.
full articles.article:
"Never trust to hosters when you are on
journey. 1t is essentially necessary that
you personally see to the cleaning, watering,
feeding, and littering of your herse, other
wise you will in all probability soon be un-
der the necessity of purchasing another, or
abandoning your journey.


"Shopld your horse lose his appetite, give
him half an ounce of nitre in bran mash
once or twice. This, with little rest, will
soon recover him.


''Should you be so unfortunate as to have
your horse foundered, by injudicious feeding
or watering before he is sufficiently cool
which is always to be apprehended when you
feed on Indian corn, or any other grain ex-
cept oats; it is advisable on the first appear
ance of founder, to take two quarts of blood
from the neck, and also to bleed in two
places lin each foot) i'll the coronet or upper
edge Of the hoof, about one inch each way
from the centre, then give purge of castor
oil one pint, calomel one drachm, after this
and if it is possible to get him out of the sta
BILE, force him to take some exercise; which
is of all others the most efficacieus remedy
and ifperseyered in however cruel and pain
full it may appear to be, seldom or never
fails to carry off the complaint in shor,
time, especially if the founder or stiffness is
not very severe. But should it be founl
impracticablc to move the horse out of q
stable, which is sometimes the case, after
hsing bled as before directed, bran poultice

full articles.headline:
TIE FARMER.

From the MiddletownSentinel.


SHAKER BARN.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Starr-I hand you for the amusement
and information of the practical farmer,
description which have verbally received
from friend of mine, living in that vicini.
ty, Of large Barn, built The last season, in
the town of Hancock Berkshire county Mass.
by the family of Shakers located in that
town. 1t is possible that in some points the
dimensions may be inaccurate; but you may
rely that they are materially correct.-Bcth
the size and form are probably unfit for any
common purposes very few farmers would
wish to collect so much forage and manure,
OF have so much stock at one place; but all
who have any experience in the business,
will agree that there is much ingenuity and
convenience in the design, for large estab-
Gshment.


The barn is built on ground inclning
southwardly, in perfect circle, and is nine
ty feet in diameter, or across 1t from side to
side. The walls are stone. % feet in height,
OF suitable thickness, and laid in lime or well
pointed on each side. Round the barn, on
the inner side, are stables forming circle,
the manger within, and suitable places over
il throw the hay or feed down; the stable
and manger occupy about 10 feet, and are 8
feet high the stables open to and from sew
eral different yards, in order to make
as many and such divisions Of their stock as
they have thought proper. The covering Of
che stables form the barn floor, which also
extends round the barn. There is but enc
large door way for entrance with teams and
loads; this is from the Northern side, from
an offset or causeway, eight feet above the
base, and of course fourteen feet below the
caves. The cart or wagon that enters with
a load, makes the whole circuit of the floor,
and after unloading comes out at the same
door; thus or 10 teams can occupy the floor
at one time in unloading, and not hinder each
other. Within this circle of the stables and
barn floor is an area or bay, as it is usually
called, which is filled with hay, &c, and
must be over sixty feet in diameter This
is pitched in and on from any side or place
most convenient, or where wanted.


The roof comes to point at the centre,
and sheds off the rain all around, something
similar to an umbrella. 1t is supported from
the inner circle of the barn floor The ROOT
boards are laid up and down, which by a
traverse saving Of the log we're all brough,
to point, and then shingled round in the u
sual mode.

full articles.headline: Nlumber For Sale.
full articles.article:
The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business carly this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand al reduced prices, whole sale or retail
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give us a call, as we have a
general assortment, consisting of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles Of various qualities; PANEL, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soncd; hearts Pine and Helnlock boIds; scant-
ling ard DIST of various qualities, lengths and
sizes; Poplar Plank, Boards and scantling; plain,
speeked and cnrlcd Maple Boards, Plank and
Scantling. Also, Cherry Scantllng; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and i variety Of other
articles not enumerated


n. b. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business will find il much to their adj
vantage to make application TO us, as We are
disposed TO sell on reasonable terms; and the
stand is we'll known 10 be as good as any i'll the
borough.


EZRA IIOOPES,


JOSEPH THOMAS.
Wilmington, ID mo. LIST, 1897, 20--tf.

fore conducted by James Ray, Esq, together

will continue the business in all its branches, at
the old Siiind, corner Of Tatnall and Queen-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,

full articles.headline: Twenty Dollars Reward.
full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, the
18th inst, an indented boy to the Coachmaking
business, named JOHN HALL: he went in com
pany with boy bound to Thomas Moore. He
IS about 10 years of age, about five feet six inches
high, thick set; speaks quick when spoken to;
has rather down look; light hair and light com
plexion-had on when lie went way, suit u
blue clothes fur hat, and boots


Whoever will secure the boy in any Jail, SO
that can get him again, shall receive the above
reward; together with reasonable charges il
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harboring said boy, at theirperil.
PETER A. HUMPHREYS.
WILMINGTON Del Ian. 25-19 at.

full articles.headline: THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION Of St.
full articles.article:
THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION Of St.
Peters Church. in the Borough of Whining
ton, return their unfeigned thanks to their Ex-
cellencics, the late and present Governors: and
also to the Honorable gentleme that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State OF Dcla-
ware, since the wear of our Lord 1922 to this
present wear of our ortts 1927, for their kind be-
ne, olence, founded on Christian philanthropy,
in extending the right hand offelowship, to their
Catholic brethren, (not in fleetlng words, but IN
real actions) to accomplish what was not IN our
power to do; which was, to finish our church,
and ay Oh the inc,imbranccs due on the church;
bv granting us lottery, and extending It, by
granting us two supplements; one Of which we
have The proceeds, received BY the Lottery and
first supplements; which was divided into four
different classes was received BY William Iarkin,
Grocer in the aforesaid thorough of Wilmington,
who acted as principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums ut money obtain
ca hy the sales Of the aforesaid four different
classes Of said Laftety-which money, the SAID
William I.arkin illegally holds from us, the Ma
nagers for the Congregation of st. Peters
Church, although we have repeatedly called on
the saitl William Larkin during the TING and term
of near five wears from the commencement OF
the firsi class Of the said Lottery, And for his
so illegally Withholding the money obtained by
the sales OF the aforesaid LOTTERY, We nave
suit at Law against the said William Larkin' as
we could not get a settlement from hun, but a
busive language and insolence, every time We
applied 10 him for such settlement.


we, the Managers Of St. Peters Church, give
tho public in general notice, that we discharge
the aforesaid William Larkn from our employ
and forbid him to transact any business as Ma
nager, Agent or for any concern, direct,
ly or indirectly, belonging to ST. Peters Church,
in the liorongh Of Wilmington, state Of pela,
ware-And also give the public notice that we
will not acknowledge nor abide by any transac.
ton done for the Church by any person Or per
sons, unless legally empowered by the Manag-
ers.


PETER PIERCE,


BERNARD M'GUIGEN,


BERNARD M'CANN,


JOHN DURNIN.


Feb IA. 1897. 22-ltp.

full articles.headline: Fattening Fowls with Potatoes.
full articles.article:
There is great profit in feeding geese, tur-
keys, and fowls Of every sort, with potatoes
and meal mixed; they will tatten in nearly
half the time that they will with any kind OF
corn or even meal by itself. The potatoes
must be bruised fine, while they are hot, and
the meal added, when the mess is given to
them y SIC. IF .4rts.

Po.asoes far Fa.ening Hogs seasoned 7vitA


-f3um.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Someryille says that the fattening Of
hogs by potatoes, is much hastened, by mix
ing small quantity Of astringent substance
among the potatoes, especially if they show
the least tendency to purging. A little alum
or Armenian bole may be used.-Re7aort Of
The British Board Of Agricul.

full articles.headline: GLUTION.
full articles.article:
G1.UTTON.
When the tir'd glutton labours through treat
He finds no relish in the sweetest meat:
He calls for something bitter something sour,
And the rich feast concludes extremely poor.


DEBATE.
Ye powers who rule the tongue, fsuch there are
And make colloquial happiness your care,
Preserve me from the thing dread and hate,
A duel in the form Of debate. Pope.

may be applied to his legs and feet, kept
constantly wet with cold water.


"Clysters of three quarts of warm water,
naxseed tea, or water cruel, ought also to be
given. and repeated, if necessary, with
handful of fine salt in either. While the
stiffness continues, the horse should be fed
upon bran mashes. with small quantity OF
oats added, and be allowed but little water,
and that not entirely cold. Exercise must
on no account be omitted.


Deane's New England Farmer says "lo
fit horse for journey, he should not be sui
fered to grow too fat and gross. lie should for
some time be kept in the stable rather than
in the pasture. and fed mostly with proven
der: but rather sparingly if he incline to be
fat He should have exercise daily to hard
en- his flesh, and keep him in the habit Of
travelling. He should be shod some days
before he begins journey, that the shoes
may be well settled to his feet, and the nails
a little rusted at the points, that they hold
the faster And the pads of the saddle should
be we'll fitted to his back SO as to hill the
holows, and bear equally on every part
And while he is on a journey he should be
stabbed every night. 1t is very destructive
! to expose horses to the dampness and cold
of the night after severe exercise. But It
would be best if neither horses nor any OF
our cattle were wholly confined to dry meat
in winter. Horses indicate this by their cat
ing snow with their hay Set basket OF
! snow within reach of horse, when he is at
his manger, and he will take mouthful
4 from each alternately. OF all juicy food for
horses in winter, writers seem to give car
rots the preference. Potatoes and turnips
! in small quantities are also recommended.
1 They have been found by experience to an
swer well instead of oats for laborng horses;
and to fasten those which are lean. Carrots
are said in the Domestic Encyclopedia to be
particularly seryiceable to broken wlnded
horses.


"Horses should not be too much deprived
of the liberty of motion, they too often
are. Close confinement after hard labour,
will be apt to abate their circnlations too
suddenly. make them chilly, and stlffcn their
joints. Horses should therefore not be
straitened for room in their stables. Stables
should not be 50 low as to prevent their toss
ing up their heads as high as they please.
Some stables have so little room over head
as to bring horses into a habit OF carrying
] their heads too low. They become afraid
TO lift them up. They should also have room
in their stables to turn their heads to any
part of their bodies, that they may defend
themselves from the biting Of insects, alav
itching, &C. And their halters should al,
ways be SO long, and their stables so wide
that they may lay conveniently Nor should
horses be so placed as to be able to deprive
each other of fodder


"Horses that are daily worked in sum-
mer, should be mostly kept on green fodder
in stables, rather than grazed in pastures
he tendance Of them will not be 50 BURDEN
some, with spot Of high and thick grass
at hand, as leading them to and from pas
tnre at the distance of quarter Of mile.
This will prevent their being often chilled
by feeding il wet nights. A large quantity
of manure will thus he saved. And verv
small quantity Of land will answer in compar-
ison with what it takes for the pasturng of
horse. Keeping sctthe and basket at
hand, horse may De pastured in this way.
IN two or three minutes, and by the time that
! the whole spot has been once moved over,
that which is first cut will be grown again.

full articles.headline: From tAe SoutAhamtton Rrrald.
full articles.article:
lowing letter. dated from the Temple Lon
don, received BY friend of his in this coun-
try, for the character of tenant quitting a
farm, regarding it as novel and curious to
agrculturists-to London agents ingenious
and instructive--and comprehensive and
amusing to the public:


Sir-I take the liberty of troubling YOU
with few inquiries, in consequence Of an
application made to me bv ----, who says
he has rented farm under you, and can re-
fer to you for his character and respectable
ty. for permission TO take an assignment of Il
lease of farm. of which have the controul
You will therefore oblige me by informing
me what is his character. Whether he is
honest, sober, frugal, industrious? Wheth-
